Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the idea that the stones at Stonehenge are moved every year to accommodate for daylight saving time.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks any evidence or support to suggest that the stones at Stonehenge are actually moved for daylight saving time.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that daylight saving time has an impact on the position of the sun and the shadows it casts, which is not true.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the presence of the stones in the meme, such as restoration efforts or jokes related to ancient monuments and daylight saving time.
